title: Third arrest linked to union probe in ACT
text:
Union associate Tuungafasi Manase who has appeared before the Royal Commission into trade unions was arrested on Wednesday night. Royal commission screenshot by Lucille Keen The competition watchdog will investigate claims the militant construction union has been involved in cartel conduct following evidence before the trade union Royal Commission.
Canberra's scaffolding sector has been under the spotlight with subcontractors telling the Royal Commission into trade union governance and corruption the union was attempting to have them all agree to a set minimum price , $16 a square metre, for jobs.
The Australian Competition and Consumer Commission said it was aware of serious allegations and evidence presented to the Commission concerning alleged cartel conduct in the construction industry in Canberra, particularly concreting and scaffolding.
ACCC Chairman Rod Sims said cartel conduct such as price fixing, anti-competitive agreements and attempts to bring about collusive arrangements were matters of "grave concern to the ACCC".
"The ACCC will be looking closely at the allegations," Mr Sims said.
"Our enquires will be conducted by the specialist team we have recently established to look at similar allegations in the construction industry arising from the Royal Commission into Trade Union Governance and Corruption."
On Wednesday, Petar Josifoski, the owner of a scaffolding company, told the Commission he was forced to walk out of a meeting with the militant construction union because of fears he could be implicated in a price-fixing scam.
Another, sub contractor John Ryan told the hearings the union met with him and other companies to discuss at set price for scaffolding work.
 Third arrest On Wednesday night a third person was arrested a result of the activities of the CFMEU in Canberra.
Tuungafasi Manase, 29, was arrested and charged with one count of perjury. He will face court on Thursday.
Mr Manase, who gave evidence before the union royal commission in early July, is an associate of former CFMEU official Fihi Kivalu, who was arrested on blackmail charges earlier this month .
Counsel assisting the commission, Jeremey Stojlar, SC, alleged Mr Kivalu demanded bribes from ACT builders in return for work.
This week builder John Domitrovic told the commission he paid $30,000 to Mr Kivalu and was instructed to make the cheques out to Mr Kivalu's wife.
Last week, former Canberra Raiders player and now union official John Lomax was arrested on for blackmail .
Mr Lomax is yet to give evidence before the Commission but is listed to do so.
The month-long hearings into the CFMEU in Canberra will conclude on Friday before resuming in Sydney next week.
Over the last month, the commission has heard from plumbing and building contractors who have claimed they were forced to pay bribes to the CFMEU and were pressured into signed union enterprise bargaining agreements in order to get work in the ACT.
